body: GROSS-Emerick. Died at age 106 of a heart attack on December 15, 2002. He passed away surrounded by his beloved wife and grandsons 23 days short of his 107th birthday and three months shy of his 71st wedding anniversary. He is survived by his wife, Violette, and children Alan and Francine, Donald and Linda. In addition he had the devotion of
title: Paid Notice: Deaths GROSS, EMERICK

body: When Robert D. Johnson, a young historian, agreed to join the Brooklyn College faculty three years ago, professors there could not believe their good fortune. He had two Harvard degrees, two books published by Harvard University Press and rave reviews from students and colleagues at other colleges where he had taught. Now some Brooklyn professors
title: Star Scholar Fights for His Future at Brooklyn College

body: EVERY year, as winter melts into spring, two books are published that in the world of football are referred to as the Bibles: specifically, draft books compiled by two football seers who divine which college players are the most promising for the National Football League. One is written by Mel Kiper, ESPN's draft analyst. Mr. Kiper has the Hair. He
title: CITYPEOPLE; The Book of Joel

body: The Public Schools Athletic League is full of two-way football players. The top players in the league are expected to play offense and defense, and even special teams. body: TAXEL - Manuel. Beloved husband of Ruth, devoted father of Madeleine, Joel and Susan, adoring grandfather of Gregg, Samantha, Michael, Alex and Elizabeth, and great-grandfather of Nathan and Zachary, died on November 24 at age 85 at his home in Brooklyn, NY. He served his country with distinction during W.W. II seeing action in the Pacific Theatre.

body: An 87-year-old woman who was struck by a hit-and-run driver on Saturday evening died early yesterday, the authorities said. The victim, Silva Mayo, was crossing the street in front of 510 Avenue J in Midwood about 6 p.m. when an eastbound vehicle hit her and left the scene, the police said. Ms. Mayo, who lived on Ocean Parkway, told the police that
title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Woman Dies After Hit-and-Run

body: IF there was one thing that became apparent soon after Mayor Bloomberg hired Joel Klein to be the city's schools chancellor, it was that the new guy had better connections than the old guy. Harold O. Levy, the departing chancellor, hired Fredda Plesser of the Securities Industry Association to be his fund-raiser for city schools. Mr. Klein landed
title: COPING; Symbolism and Reality in the School System

body: Farmingdale has always been a running team, but in the Nassau Conference I title game the Dalers took their strategy to extremes. Farmingdale (9-1) avenged its only loss with a 26-0 shutout of Baldwin (8-2) to win the championship at Hofstra's Shuart Stadium on Friday night. The Dalers racked up 356 yards on 47 carries and did not attempt a pass.
title: HIGH SCHOOL FOOTBALL; Old-Fashioned Football: A Title Without a Pass

body: Growing up in Kensington three decades ago, Keith Rowan discovered something cool on his forays through town. ''I'd go with my friends to Brooklyn College,'' Mr. Rowan recalled, ''and knowing there was an observatory there, we'd go banging on the door during the day.'' Since observatories generally come to life at night, Mr. Rowan's tactics didn't
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: MIDWOOD; Stargazers Mourn Loss On the Wings of Pigeons And in the Urban Glare

body: IN the end, a great slice of pizza is defined by the quality of its ingredients and their ratio to one other. An exemplary slice should have discrete sections of cheese and sauce and a crust that is thin but not too thin. Most pizza these days has a barely visible layer of sauce -- it's as though the sauce has gone into exile. Here are six places
title: Where 'Gimme a Slice' Will Always Bring an Echo

body: WHAT'S the best way to set New Yorkers to bickering? Ask where to find the best slice of pizza in the city. No subject starts a battle faster -- not bagels or hot dogs or chopped liver, not even the primacy of the Rangers or the fastest route to J.F.K. Pizza, introduced to New York in 1905 by Gennaro Lombardi, who saw it as a way to use up the
title: Pizza 2002: The State Of the Slice

body: People in Brooklyn and in White Plains yesterday called Tom Golisano a liar and untrustworthy and sent him the message that he has been nothing but a big pain in the neck. Mr. Golisano was delighted. The Independence Party candidate for governor was the target of two noisy demonstrations yesterday, organized by supporters of Gov. George E. Pataki,
title: Heckling by Pataki Backers Only Encourages Golisano

body: SEMYON PUNDIK, 76, and Iosef Kruglyak, 75, never knew each other on the Eastern Front. The two men from Ukraine, among more than 1,000 World War II veterans of the Red Army now living in Brighton Beach, Brooklyn, met only a few years ago. Yet when they talk about one another, they use the word ''family.'' Now, they anticipate the death they thought
title: URBAN TACTICS; They Fought Side by Side, and Long to Be Buried That Way

body: New Rochelle quarterback Pete Oswald stood on the sideline in the fourth quarter yesterday knowing that he would have a chance to lead his team downfield and break a 19-19 tie against Mount Vernon. After the Huguenots' loss last week to North Rockland, Oswald knew this was his chance to redeem himself and lead his team to to a division title.
title: HIGH SCHOOL FOOTBALL; New Rochelle's Late Drive Clinches Class AA South Title

body: BEDFORD-Pauline (nee Allalouf). Age 77, passed away October 11, 2002 after a brave battle. Paula was raised on the Lower East Side, was a truly devoted mother, and never knew how smart she was. title: Paid Notice: Deaths BEDFORD, PAULINE (NEE ALLALOUF)

body: Poly Prep took the lead late in the game and then withstood a rally in the last minute to come away with an 18-15 victory yesterday over Delbarton of New Jersey in front of a home crowd in Brooklyn. ''They're one of the top teams in New Jersey,'' Poly Prep's first-year head coach, Craig Jacoby, said of Delbarton. ''It really shows what our kids are
title: HIGH SCHOOL FOOTBALL; Poly Prep Foils Last Play To Turn Back Delbarton

body: The geography of Jewish New York is undergoing a gradual but striking transformation. Orthodox Jews' numbers are expanding in neighborhoods that once held an eclectic mix of Jewish beliefs -- Conservative, Reform and nonobservant, as well as Orthodox. As the longtime residents steadily depart for the suburbs, neighborhoods like Flatbush and Midwood
title: Judaism Takes Different Turns; In Places, Blocks of Orthodoxy

body: An 18-year-old man was shot and killed early yesterday in Midwood, the police said. The man, whose name was not immediately released, was shot just before 4 a.m. on Ocean Parkway between Avenues J and K. The man was taken to Community Hospital of Brooklyn, where he died about 20 minutes later, officials said. The police said that no further details
title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Man Shot and Killed

author: George Packer is the author, most recently, of ''Blood of the Liberals.''
body: One Saturday morning in November 1994, Ramsey Clark, attorney general under President Johnson and more recently a spokesman for radical Arab causes, met in his Manhattan office with a criminal defense lawyer named Lynne Stewart. title: Left Behind

body: In the 72 years since Brooklyn College opened, generations of future film stars have passed through its halls. Dominic Chianese, class of 1961, went on to become Uncle Junior on ''The Sopranos,'' and Jimmy Smits, class of 1980, graduated to ''L.A. Law'' and ''N.Y.P.D. Blue.'' The girl, Tzitorah Gelb of East 29th Street, was declared dead at Kings County Hospital Center after being struck by a silver Lexus on East 29th Street between Avenues K and L. title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Girl, 4, Killed In Hit-And-Run

body: It is time for back-to-school shopping, a season of beleaguered parents dragging recalcitrant children through the malls in search of corduroys and turtlenecks. But savvy shoppers scoff at them as amateurs. Those in the know are buying summer things now. These self-described supershoppers know the retailers' merchandise and sales year. They use
title: Want Back-to-School Bargains? Shop in February; For the Most Dedicated Discount Hunters, Timing Is Money

body: A teenager whose suicide in a Harlem shelter hotel room last week raised concern about the city's social service system was buried yesterday as friends, relatives and city officials mourned a short life shattered by deep despair. The teenager, Jason-Eric Wilson, 16, took an overdose of medication last Monday in the hotel room where he, his father,
title: Mourning a Life Shortened by Despair

body: Everyone knew Jason-Eric Wilson was a boy with troubles and a troubled mind. His depression and anxiety, which first emerged in seventh grade, grew much worse last year, as his family moved from one relative to the next after eviction from their Brooklyn home. Within the past 10 months, he was hospitalized twice for mental illness. But in the last
title: Mentally Ill Boy Kills Himself in Shelter Hotel

body: The Republicans who control the State Senate tried to persuade two, and possibly three, Brooklyn Democrats to switch parties this year, and at least one is likely to make the jump, Senate officials in both parties say. While drawing new district boundaries earlier this year, Senate Republicans promised favorable districts to Democrats who sounded
title: Senate G.O.P. Courts Democrats Who Might Switch

author: Michael Shapiro's next book, ''The Last Good Season: Brooklyn, the Dodgers and Their Final Pennant Race Together,'' is due out next year.
body: I was 4 years old when the Dodgers left Brooklyn, but unlike the team, I stayed. I never went to Ebbets Field. I never even saw it. I lived in Brooklyn until I was 21 and when I, too, finally left, I did so still believing that had the Dodgers not abandoned the borough for Los Angeles, Brooklyn would have been altogether different, not the flat,
title: MY BROOKLYN; The Team That's Filling the Void the Dodgers Left Behind

body: When Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg recently publicized his opposition to parole for a man convicted of killing two police officers in 1971, it also sent a message to Councilman Charles Barron, a self-described black revolutionary who has made bales of hay out of annoying the leaders on both sides of City Hall. Since taking office in January, Mr.
title: Adding Charm to Revolution; But Some Say Charles Barron Risks Going Too Far

body: Nathan's Hot Whale Q. I heard that the carcass of a whale was once on display in Coney Island. Why? A. It was indeed, and it was put there to entice people to eat. In 1954, Nathan Handwerker, founder of Nathan's Famous, the hot dog emporium on the Boardwalk, was vacationing in Miami Beach and had left the store under the watch of his son, Murray.
title: F.Y.I.

body: Three of the 19 present and former plumbing inspectors who were charged this week with extorting payoffs from New York contractors had been indicted and cleared of the same crimes nearly a decade ago, records show. In a reminder of the seemingly ingrained culture of corruption that has plagued the City Buildings Department, the criminal complaints
title: 3 Inspectors Faced Charges Once Before

body: June Jordan, who came of age as a poet when the voices of black female writers were just beginning to be heard, died on June 14 at her home in Berkeley, Calif. She was 65. The cause was breast cancer, which she fought for a decade, said Adrienne Torff, a friend. Like the careers of Audre Lord and Alice Walker, Ms. Jordan's was forged by the black
title: June Jordan, 65, Poet and Political Activist

body: A grand total of eight people showed up yesterday for the matinee of Woody Allen's latest movie, ''Hollywood Ending,'' one month out of the box and now playing in exactly one theater in Manhattan, a $4.95-a-ticket discount house in Times Square. Because of technical problems, the screening was canceled. Downtown, Mr. Allen's real-life courtroom
title: Curse of the Jaded Audience: Woody Allen, in Art and Life

Robeson's Brooklyn rival, Boys and Girls, led by Stacey Ann Livingston, kept pace with three victories of its own. Robeson's Erica Alston won
title: PLUS: TRACK AND FIELD; Brooklyn Rivals Each Win 3 Events

body: Kate Lawson of Sacred Heart High School of Hempstead, N.Y., and Toya Woods of New Rochelle (N.Y.) High won two girls' events each, and Percy Addo-Yobo of Iona Prep was a boys' double winner yesterday at the Mount St. Michael Relays in the Bronx. Lawson captured the long jump at 16 feet 101/2 inches and the 400-meter intermediate hurdles in 1:06.72.
title: PLUS: TRACK AND FIELD; DOUBLE WINNERS

body: Anger over the escalating conflict in the Middle East spilled into the streets of Manhattan, Brooklyn and the suburbs yesterday in the form of animated but mostly orderly marches, rallies and news conferences that alternately denounced either the Israelis or Palestinians as terrorists. In Times Square, at Brooklyn Borough Hall, and in Jersey City
title: Demonstrations Highlight Deep Divisions Over Growing Conflict in Middle East

body: Like a relentless drama too painful to watch but too compelling to turn away from, the conflict in the Middle East has put knots in New York-area residents' stomachs and suicide bombers in their nightmares. The turmoil is geographically distant, they say, but with its echoes of Sept. 11, and its passion, it is emotionally all too close. People
title: MIDEAST TURMOIL: VOICES; New Yorkers Tell of Fear, Anger and Fatigue Over Mideast

title: Paid Notice: Deaths LEVY, ALBERT

body: When Congress overhauled the nation's welfare system in 1996, it preserved food stamps as a federal entitlement for the poor and disabled. Yet thousands of needy New Yorkers who qualified for disability benefits lost their food stamps automatically when they were cut from the welfare rolls. Though state and city officials will not estimate how many
title: Suit to Seek Food Stamps for Thousands Wrongly Denied Them

title: Motive Is Sought in Killing of Yeshiva Student

body: At 17, Alicia Harper thinks she has found the great love of her life. Yet ask Ms. Harper why she loves education so and the words do not come so
title: 19 Who Defied the Odds Get Times Scholarships

body: Ira Waldbaum, who dropped out of college to help run his family's six small grocery stores in Brooklyn and ended up building what was at one time the nation's 12th largest supermarket chain, died Wednesday at a hospital in Boca Raton, Fla. He was 74. The family could not be reached yesterday for the cause of death. Mr. Waldbaum lived in Delray
title: Ira Waldbaum, 74; Built Northeast Grocery Chain

body: For a week after Nikita Rozenblyum witnessed the jet hurtling into the World Trade Center, he could not concentrate on his schoolwork, let alone the math research project he intended to submit for the Intel Science Talent Search. His classmate Philip Ernst, by contrast, deflected the world that had gone surreal with a dose of teenage bravado. He
title: At Stuyvesant, Kudos for Scientific Creativity in the Shadow of Ruin

body: Tristan Christy was awakened one morning last March by neighbors banging on his door to warn of a fire in the apartment above him. They were telling everyone in the building to get out. Tristan, now 14, lived there with his grandmother, and they both got out safely, though it meant he would have to go to school without a shower. He thought
title: The Neediest Cases; Bereft by Fire and Grandmother's Death

title: A NATION CHALLENGED: PORTRAITS OF GRIEF: THE VICTIMS; Loquacious Disney Fan, Aspiring Firefighter, Young Spirit, Happy Host
